climbs.name: Waste Age
climbs.fa: Rey DeCastro, Chris Marchese, Steve Zich- and god knows who else

content.description: Right of Dobie Gillis is a bolted face climb. Stiff moves and maybe stiffer still now that stuff has broken.
content.location: see approach on PATC/Skyline wall page.

content.description: Large (fist-size+) crack at the beginning which can be slightly hard to protect.  Climb to a good ledge then another crack to a traverse to climber's left.  Top out the same as Rhodey Crack.  Upper crack can be wet which makes protection challenging and climbing slippery.
content.protection: Small/med sized pro smaller pieces (.2-.4) possibly needed in the middle.  Slightly run-out at the start, especially for a new leader.
content.location: Climber's right of Rhodey Crack.  Same belay location and scramble up to the climb.

content.description: Interesting moves to reach top out at the end of a ramp/crack.  Once on a ledge climber's right all very low angle to top.
content.protection: Need a larger piece (6 or big hex) to protect crux.
content.location: Climber's right of Vegemite, same belay spot as Vegemite and Rhodey Crack.

content.description: A left-leaning crack in a corner system that rewards good jam/stem/lieback technique. The exit moves through the roof are a bit tricky, and can be difficult to protect. (The eponymous rusty bong has been removed from the crack and was last seen several years ago.)
content.location: Start at the base of the huge, left-facing corner/crack system.

content.description: Crux is in the middle reaching a vertical crack half-way up.
content.protection: Natural/gear pro.  Mostly smaller pro (.4 to 1)
content.location: Descend keyhole/downclimb near large boulder then head skiers right, scramble up some large boulders to a belay position below this climb (as well as Thrash and Vegemite).  This is directly next to (climber's right) piton crack.

content.description:
Climb the slightly awkward but easy corner(ish) system until you can traverse left to widely spaced bolts that lead to the fixed pin anchor shared with Dobie Gillis and Waste Age. 

  The crux is near the end and of the slab variety.  Worth doing if you are there but not a reason to go!  The top can be wet with seepage so look before you climb.
content.protection: Medium to small gear and draws.
content.location: One of the 3 routes on the short face below the blank and overhanging headwall in the middle of the wall.  All 3 share a fixed pin anchor under the headwall in a horizontal crack.  This is the route slightly right of the anchor starting in a small corner system.

content.description: Around the corner to the right of Rusty Bong is a steeply left leaning crack system up high. Near the ground is Fist/OW crack, and a bush next to it. Starting up the crack is supposed to be 5.8+, or climb awkwardly through the bush and up the slab. Continue up the crack, and follow it once it starts to move left on a delicate traverse. Either follow the upper left leaning crack, or traverse further left to the vertical crack/fins straight up. Both variations are about the same grade. Gear anchor up top, and whoever cleans it will have to walk off.
content.protection: Pro up to 2" for the route, I remember placing a #2 and a #3 BD C4 as well as a stopper for the gear anchor up top. A red tricam in a horizontal slot protects the traverse to backup the questionable piton.
content.location: Climber's right, around the corner from Rusty Bong. Whoever cleans the anchor will have to walk off. If you build the anchor right above where you top out, the easiest way off is to the climber's right, which has an easy but exposed/lichen covered slab move, so be careful.

content.description:
This is a link-up and a classic one at that. 

  Locate the widening crack in a left-facing corner below the obvious bomb-bay chimney high above.  Climb the corner using the widening crack (#5 cam helpful) and layback techniques (this is PATC Lieback).  When you top out the crack, continue up to the base of Bomb-bay Crack.  You can either continue up or make a belay.  If you only have one #5 and no #6, I'd recommend making a belay. 

  Continue up into the widening chimney, facing to climbers right.  Near the outer portion, climb the big eye-bolt and move up to small ledge outside the chimney where there are two manky pins.  The #6 (or BigBros...possibly the #5 can go) is helpful here...otherwise you're running it out. Continue up either face climbing or using wide techniques.  If going wide (I had to...womp womp), heel-toe camming, chicken-winging and arm-bars will see you through.  Good options up top for an anchor with medium gear.

Start to the right of the Keyhole and send the wide, right-facing flake. #4 & #5 are helpful to protect.  

  Once you finish the flake, step up and go around the corner (a bit airy) to join Keyhole Left.
content.protection: Standar rack.  Build an anchor at the top of Keyhole Left
content.location: Right of the keyhole. Finish on Keyhole Left

content.description:
Send the left facing corner to a ledge on the left. Continue up over the bulge, using holds on the left, then once you pull up, use the crack system on the right.  The bulge is more difficult than the "scramble up" description contained in the Horst book.  

  Make your belay with all the tourists coming by to ask you how the rope gets to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack with a #4 or #5 useful for protecting close to the top out. Build an anchor.
content.location: Start at the left facing crack, left of the keyhole. Walk off back to the main descent gulley.

content.description:
The crux is not getting whacked in the face (or impaled) by the Hemlock branches.  Not sure how you climb this line without leaning on the tree.  

  There are actually two cracks that you can send.  The left one seems to protect better.
content.protection: #4 and then a #6 if you decide to finish on Bombay.
content.location:
Route is located right in from of the Hemlock tree. 

  There is no anchor. Once you get to the horizontal under the mini-roof, you can either move around the corner left and finish on Bombay Crack. Or, traverse right (save a #4) to get on Fern Crack, in which case you'll have some serious drag. 

  This line is pining for a bolted anchor and some tree trimming.

content.description: Jam the fist sized crack to a stance, then jam/layback the corner/crack above to a bulge, pull the bulge and squeeze through a small chimney.

Technical granite roof, face and crack climbing.  One of the best 5.10's on the mountain. 

  This route is described as "dicey" in the Horst guide but it's actually well protected and the old bolt has been replaced.  Get on it!
content.protection: Standard rack. Doubles in #1 & #2 C4 I believe.  A #3 might be useful at the top but isn't mandatory. The bolt was replaced in December 2014
content.location: Climbers left of Dobie Gillis.  Start in the hand crack splitting the low roof

content.description: Nice crack climbing to a bolt, then traverse to anchors. Fun route, bring tape.
content.location: Find Waste Age, the tough-looking 50 foot bolted face. Dobie is just to the left, and ends by traversing right to the same anchors.

content.description: Blocky climbing leads to good and varied crack climbing

Establish on a basalt jug/undercling block and escape left out of the overhang on coarse granite jugs to 3 short ragged cracks and a little ledge. Easier fun slab and crack climbing all the way to the top.
content.protection: gear to 3", doubles in 1 and 2 camalot could be useful.  walk off.
content.location: Start in a small basalt cave 20ft right of the keyhole feature.

content.description:
Extremely exciting topping out if you don't have a #6 for the top.  I didn't have a #6 and instead placed a semi-suitable #5 about 12 feet below the top.   

  Either chicken wing or face climb on some delicate holds to top out. Wild, wild, wild, and wonderful.
content.location:
Locate the obvious chimney.   

  Climb one of the vegetated cracks to reach the base of the chimney.  An alternate, and preferred start, is to hop on PATC Lieback.  

  Build an anchor. You might as well set up an anchor on Fern Crack, which you can then use as a rap line to avoid the down climb.

content.description: This crack runs the length of the wall, with a wide section at about 30ft.

Good rock climbing, great setting with a stupendous view of the surrounding Blue Ridge, best crag on the mountain when it's warm, usually a nice breeze going, and it's easy to set topropes. Grades range from 5.5 to easy 5.12. Everyone's happy at this crag (as long as they bring tape-GRIPPY rock!)
